Ought but the want of discipline condemne;
To which defect, since time, true ingenie
And practise yeeld the onely remedie:
O that god Mars more oft might sing his dittie,
In the soft eares of this our peacefull cittie,
And that the greedy gripe, that grasps his purse
Fast in his fist, and grudges to disburse
His coyne to such good vse, would learne to know
ThatNil Spartā perdat nisi cara pecunia facta. Oracle, which in times past did show,
That nothing could the Spartan state disioyne,
Except they made too much account of coyne;
And that our eldest sonnes of idle ease,
Whom nothing but the Taylors cut can please,
Would turne superfluous rags of wretched pride,
To plates of steele, lay oftentimes aside
Their slender switches for strong staues of Ash,
And change perfumes for sulphurie powders flash:
But vnto such I wish this good in vaine,
As I began, so must I end againe,
With Londons Mars-adornd Artillerie,
Her onely Nurse of armes yong Infantrie,
Bellonas spring where streames of knowledge floe,
Garden of Mars where plants of valour grow,
(Thrise worthy spirits) euer may you liue,
In fames faire booke, whose industrie doth giue,
Life to the loue of armes, who both with paine
And large expence, the schoole of Mars maintaine,
And since the fier of your forward harts
To all good actions both in armes and arts,
Warmes the cold hopes of London, to renew
Her ancient orders, chiefly vnto you
I by this pen-man do commend this storie,
As the true mirrour of our Londons glorie.
This said, the helme-deckt goddesse tooke her rise
Vpon her speare, and vanisht from our eyes,
Leauing the souldier and my selfe agast;
For he, who selfe-loue-swolne sought to blast
Our Londons fame, with enuious breath before,
Did euer since her noble name adore;
And by Minerua, as I was foretaught,
Lest her swift vision flying from my thought,
I should at last haue lost what I did thinke,
I thus did limme the Visions wings with inke.

div.head: Illustrations. "Who Barrons at that time haue stiled bene.
div.p:
THe youth of this cittie in times past despising such effeminate games as we now vse, which rather induce both body and minde to vice then to vertue, didFitz. Step. • e situ & no
• ltate Lond. euery Friday in Lent practise feates of armes on horsebacke with disarmed lances and shields, and did also sight battailes on the water, thereby shewing, how seruiceable they would be in martiall affaires; this was their practise in the reigne of Henrie the second, many of them being called Barons, for after anno 37. of Henrie the third, I readeOut of Ra. Holl. in Hen. • . that certaine of the court comming with a humour of contempt and scorne to behold their exercise, & giuing reprochfull words to those Londoners, which were there called Barons, did suffer for their derision such stripes and wounds, that the king caused the cittizens to pay 1000. markes for the healing.
div.q: "Which did illustrate those two famous nights.
div.p:
Meaning the vigels of Saint Iohn Baptist and Saint Peter, when that famous marching watch consisting of 2000. besides the standing watches, were maintained in this cittie. It continued from the reigne of Henrie the 3 •
vntill the reigne an. 31 of Henrie the eight, in which yeare it was laide downe by licence frō the king, for that the cittte had then bin charged with the leauie of a muster of fifteene thousand men, neither was it reuiued againe, vntill anno 2. of Edward the sixth, by Sir Iohn Gresham then Lord Maior, since whose time the like watch in London hath not bene seene; I will not here dispute the conueniencie thereof, onely note the words of a certaine book
dedicatdd by aIohn Moūtgomer. cittizen anno 1585. to Sir Thomas Pullison, then Lord Maior and the Aldermen, the words are these, Artificers of diuers sorts were therby well set to worke, none but rich men charged, poore men releeued, old souldiers, wherein the safetie and defence of euery commonwealth consisteth, maintained, armour annd weapons through this occasion ready prepared whereas by intermission armorours want worke, souldiers out of practise, weapons ouergrowne with rust, few or none good being prouided, &c. and so goes on with an exhortation to reuiue tht same: but as this, so the like good orders are vanisht and the fruite of sloth and couetousnesse growne vp, though some haue sought to restore the customes of our countrie, amongst whom I may not forget the good endeuour of that worthy Gentleman, Master Hugh Ophley Sherriffe of London, who did deuise the martiall shew of Prince Arthur, onely to giue life to decayed Archerie the good endeuour of whom and of all those that now or hereafter shall immitate the like attempt, cannot want a praise-worthie remembrance with posteritie.
div.q: VVhere kings, great Peeres, and many noble dame.
div.p: King Henrie the eight approuing this marching watch, as an auncient commendable custome of this cittie, lest it should decay through neglect or couetousnesse, in the first yeare of his reigne, came priuately disguised in one of his guards coates into Cheape on Midsommer euen, and seeing the same at that time performed to his content to countenance it, and make it more glorious by the presence of his person,Raph. Hol. in Hen. 8. came after on S. Peters Euen with Queene Katherine attended by a noble traine, riding in royall state to the Kings head in Cheap • e, there to behold the same, and after anno. 15. of his reigne Christerne king of Denmarke with his Queene being then in England, was conducted through the cittie to the kings head in Cheape, there to see the same.
div.q: When London twise ten ensignes did dispreade
div.p:
Both the late Muster of Wednesday, the 27. of September and that before, on Tewsday, the eight of August anno 1615. my Muse hath briefly noted, whose souldiers for their armes and furniture, both for seruice and shew, were well and rightly appointed, imitating the old Romans, in their garnish of feathers, which, as it is a sightNich. Mac. in his art of warre. lib. 2. fol. 21. braue and terrible to the enemie, so is it goodly and delightfull to friends: In their demeanour I noted these two defects, ignorance of order, and neglect of their Captaines command, the knowledge of the first cannot bee had without time and practise, nor respect of the last (except in the more ingenuous man) without more authoritie to inforce it: so that asFran. Guic. hist. lib. 2.
Maximilian the Emperour being with king Henrie 8. at the siege of Tourwaine (where wearing S. Georges crosse, hee receiued salaire for seruice as the king of Englands souldier) gaue his iudgement vpon triall, that in matters of warre the English were then more resolute, then well aduised: and lesse subtile and polliticke, then well disciplined and trained, so may it be here said of the late Muster, with which I conclude, that they were more rash and turbulent, then discreet and wel aduised, & lesse instructed & trained then will furnished and appointed.
